Stones
switch
Click
JANUARY,AQUARIUS, GARNET STONE Garnets are a group of silicate minerals that have been used since the Bronze Age as gemstones and abrasives.
FEBRUARY,PICSIS, AMETHYST A violet variety of quartz, the ancient Greeks wore amethyst and carved drinking vessels from it in the belief that it would prevent intoxication.

MARCH, ARIES, BLOODSTONE The red inclusions are supposed to resemble spots of blood, hence the name bloodstone. The name heliotrope derives from various ancient notions about the manner in which the mineral reflects light.
APRIL, TAURUS, DIAMOND Commonly, natural sapphires are cut and polished into gemstones and worn in jewelry.
MAY, GEMINI, AGATE Although agates may be found in various kinds of host rock, they are classically associated with volcanic rocks and can be common in certain metamorphic rocks.
JUNE, CANCER, EMERALD Emeralds, like all colored gemstones, are graded using four basic parametersâ€“the four Cs of connoisseurship: color, clarity, cut and carat weight.
JULY, LEO, ONYX Onyx primarily refers to the parallel banded variety of the silicate mineral chalcedony.
AUGUST, VIRGO, CARNELIAN Carnelian (also spelled cornelian[2]) is a brownish-red mineral commonly used as a semi-precious gemstone.
SEPTEMBER, LIBRA, CHRYSOLITE Peridot is one of the few gemstones that occur in only one color: an olive-green.

OCTOBER, SCORPIO, BERYL Pure beryl is colorless, but it is frequently tinted by impurities; possible colors are green, blue, yellow, red (the rarest), and white. Beryl is also an ore source of beryllium.
NOVEMBER, SAGITTARIUS, TOPAZ Topaz crystallizes in the orthorhombic system, and its crystals are mostly prismatic terminated by pyramidal and other faces.
DECEMBER, CAPRICORN, RUBY The quality of a ruby is determined by its color, cut, and clarity, which, along with carat weight, affect its value.
